Legal_Issue: Whether Harry meets the residence requirements under s. 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Application_Facts: Harry was absent from Canada for most of the four-year period preceding his application, pursuing studies abroad with only sporadic visits to Canada
Court_Ruling: The appeal was dismissed; Harry does not meet the residency requirement
Defendant_Behavior: Extended absence from Canada while studying abroad
Grounds_for_Claim: Insufficient physical presence in Canada during the required period
Legal_Standard: Residency requirement of at least three out of the past four years in Canada
Assessment_Factor: Physical presence, intent to reside, lifestyle centralization
Procedural_Issue: Appeal from Citizenship Judge to Federal Court Trial Division
Evidence_Used: Records of travel, property ownership in Canada, duration of stays
Evidence_Assessed: Harry's efforts to centralize lifestyle in Canada, such as property ownership
Governing_Rule: Section 5(1)(c) requires three years of physical residence in Canada within four years prior to application
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of sufficient documentation or proof of physical presence meeting statutory threshold
Cause_Description: Harry's application for citizenship was denied due to insufficient residency days as per s. 5(1)(c)
Evidence_Handling: Court reviewed legislative intent and definition of 'residence'
Evidence_Issues: Sporadic visits do not constitute legal residence under the Act
Evidence_Assessment: Property ownership and intent do not substitute for physical presence
Decision_Rationale: Statutory residency requirement is based on physical presence, not intent or asset location
Evidentiary_Issues: Inadequate evidence of continuous or sufficient physical presence
Legal_Standard_Applied: Objective interpretation of residency under s. 5(1)(c)
